Fiction

THE BROKER, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $27.95.) The C.I.A. arranges a presidential pardon for a power broker who may know crucial secrets, laying a trap for the foreign intelligence service that wants him dead.
THE DA VINCI CODE, by Dan Brown. (Doubleday, $24.95; special illustrated edition, $35.) A murder at the Louvre leads to the discovery of a secret society.
THE FIVE PEOPLE YOU MEET IN HEAVEN, by Mitch Albom. (Hyperion, $19.95.) An old man who died rescuing a little girl finds that all is explained in the afterlife.

SURVIVOR IN DEATH, by J. D. Robb. (Putnam, $23.95.) In 2059, Lt. Eve Dallas has an eyewitness to the brutal murder of a family: the sole survivor, a 9-year-old girl; by Nora Roberts, writing pseudonymously.
STATE OF FEAR, by Michael Crichton. (HarperCollins, $27.95.) Reverse eco-terrorists create natural disasters to convince the public that global warming is real.
CONVICTION, by Richard North Patterson. (Random House, $25.95.) A lawyer comes to believe that her client -- who is on death row -- may be innocent.
BY ORDER OF THE PRESIDENT, by W. E. B. Griffin. (Putnam, $26.95.) An Army officer tries to thwart a terrorist plot to crash a stolen 727 into the Liberty Bell.
*I AM CHARLOTTE SIMMONS, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $28.95.) A smart, innocent freshman is amazed by what she finds at a prestigious university.
CHAINFIRE, by Terry Goodkind. (Tor/Tom Doherty, $29.95.) The 10th volume of the ''Sword of Truth'' fantasy series.
A SALTY PIECE OF LAND, by Jimmy Buffett. (Little, Brown, $27.95.) A cowboy's life is changed when a 101-year-old woman hires him to be a lighthouse keeper.
PREP, by Curtis Sittenfeld. (Random House, $21.95.) A scholarship student encounters a world of privilege at an expensive boarding school in Massachusetts.
LABYRINTH OF EVIL, by James Luceno. (Lucas/Del Rey/Ballantine, $25.95.) A new ''Star Wars'' novel, featuring Anakin Skywalker and Obi-Wan Kenobi.
THE REAL MOTHER, by Judith Michael. (Morrow, $24.95.) Forced to take care of her sisters and brother, a young woman learns lessons about parenthood.
THE LAST KINGDOM, by Bernard Cornwell. (HarperCollins, $25.95.) In ninth-century England, a warrior must decide where his loyalties lie.

GILEAD, by Marilynne Robinson. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $23.) A story of fathers and sons that reaches back to the abolitionist movement and into the 1950's, narrated by a 76-year-old Iowa pastor who is dying.

*KAFKA ON THE SHORE, by Haruki Murakami. (Knopf, $25.95.) Tracing the intersecting lives of two characters: a boy who is fleeing an Oedipal prophecy and a witless old man with the ability to talk to cats.

List
Nonfiction
BLINK, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Little, Brown, $25.95.) The author of ''The Tipping Point'' explores the importance of hunch and instinct to the workings of the mind.
COLLAPSE, by Jared Diamond. (Viking, $29.95.) A historical investigation, by the author of ''Guns, Germs, and Steel,'' into why some societies succeed while others fail.
AMERICA (The BOOK), by Jon Stewart, Ben Karlin, David Javerbaum et al. (Warner, $24.95.) ''The Daily Show'' offers a lavishly illustrated parody of a civics textbook.
MEN IN BLACK, by Mark R. Levin. (Regnery, $27.95.) A lawyer and conservative commentator enumerates ways in which ''the Supreme Court is destroying America.'' (+)

GOD'S POLITICS, by Jim Wallis. (HarperSanFrancisco, $24.95.) An evangelical Christian argues that Democrats must ''take back the faith'' and not allow conservative Republicans to hijack the Bible. (+)
SECRETS & MYSTERIES OF THE WORLD, by Sylvia Browne. (Hay House, $19.95.) The self-proclaimed psychic tries to explain the inexplicable.
102 MINUTES, by Jim Dwyer and Kevin Flynn. (Times Books/Holt, $26.) Two journalists at The New York Times describe people's struggle to survive inside the World Trade Center on Sept. 11.
WITNESS, by Amber Frey. (ReganBooks/HarperCollins, $25.95.) A memoir by the California massage therapist who testified for the prosecution in the murder trial of Scott Peterson.
DEAR SENATOR, by Essie Mae Washington-Williams and William Stadiem. (ReganBooks/HarperCollins, $24.95.) A memoir by the mixed-race daughter of Strom Thurmond.
SMASHED, by Koren Zailckas. (Viking, $21.95.) A young woman recalls her excessive drinking throughout high school and college.
ANIMALS IN TRANSLATION, by Temple Grandin and Catherine Johnson. (Scribner, $25.) How autism can help lead to an understanding of the brains, emotions and talents of animals.
WINNING THE FUTURE, by Newt Gingrich. (Regnery, $27.95.) The former speaker of the House proposes a 21st-century ''Contract With America.'' (+)

*IT'S MY PARTY TOO, by Christine Todd Whitman. (Penguin Press, $24.95.) The former governor of New Jersey and former head of the Environmental Protection Agency lays out her vision for Republicans. (+)
TORI AMOS: PIECE BY PIECE, by Tori Amos and Ann Powers. (Broadway, $23.95.) A memoir by the singer-songwriter.
CHRONICLES: Volume One, by Bob Dylan. (Simon & Schuster, $24.) Recollections and observations from the singer-songwriter.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended Feb. 12, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 50,000 other retailers, statistically weighted to represent all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (+) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available at The New York Times on the Web: nytimes.com/books.
Editors' Choice Other recent books of particular interest
AN END TO SUFFERING: The Buddha in the World, by Pankaj Mishra. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25.) An intellectual autobiography: what Mishra has learned from the Buddha's legacy.
PLEASE DON'T COME back FROM THE MOON, by Dean Bakopoulos. (Harcourt, $23.) When the fathers in the Rust Belt town of this novel abandon it en masse, their sons take over.
THE RISE OF THE INDIAN ROPE TRICK: How a Spectacular Hoax Became History, by Peter Lamont. (Thunder's Mouth, $22.) Delicious!
EMPIRE RISING, by Thomas Kelly. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25.) A muscular historical novel in which the Irish erect the Empire State Building in a cheerfully corrupt New York.
IN THE ROSE GARDEN OF THE MARTYRS: A Memoir of Iran, by Christopher de Bellaigue. (HarperCollins, $26.95.) Unofficial insights from a deeply anxious land where much is veiled.
RONALD REAGAN AND HIS QUEST TO ABOLISH NUCLEAR WEAPONS, by Paul Lettow. (Random House, $25.95.) A scholar sees a shrewd dove dominating his hawk environment.
THIS IS A VOICE FROM YOUR PAST: New and Selected Stories, by Merrill Joan Gerber. (Ontario Review, $23.95.) Disturbingly inconclusive stories of lives interrupted by glitches.
DAMNED IF I DO: Stories, by Percival Everett. (Graywolf, paper, $15.) Quiet, intelligent tales, alert to place, often tall (as when fish talk).
THE DISPLACED OF CAPITAL, by Anne Winters. (University of Chicago, paper, $14.) A nature poet unleashed in New York, Marxian, Wordsworthian, enraged with the status quo.
BIG BANG: The Origin of the Universe, by Simon Singh. (Fourth Estate/HarperCollins, $27.95.) The biography, over several centuries, of the concept of an expanding universe.

YOU ARE NOT THE ONE: Stories, by Vestal McIntyre. (Carroll & Graf, paper, $13.95.) Elegant fiction, written around situations improbable but not impossible, like a pet octopus that grows too large for its tank.
The full reviews of these and other recent books are on the Web: nytimes.com/books
